content:
Diagnosis:	Metastatic pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with liver metastases

I reviewed [redacted name] today for assessment during cycle 4 of capecitabine and temozolomide combination therapy. The treatment was initiated following disease progression on previous lanreotide therapy in January 2024. Initial molecular profiling had identified a SMARCA4 mutation.

She has tolerated the treatment reasonably well with grade 1 palmar-plantar syndrome and mild fatigue, managing to maintain her work schedule with some adjustments. Her main symptoms of intermittent abdominal discomfort and early satiety have improved since starting treatment. Performance status remains 0.

Recent CT scan from 15/4/24 shows stable disease with no growth in the pancreatic primary (stable at 4.2cm) and stable appearance of the multiple liver metastases (largest lesion in segment 7 unchanged at 3.1cm). Chromogranin A has decreased from 325 to 240 (normal range <100).

On examination today, abdomen is soft and non-tender with no hepatomegaly. Blood tests show stable liver function and adequate bone marrow reserve for continued treatment.

The plan is to continue with cycle 5 of capecitabine/temozolomide at full dose. We will arrange repeat CT imaging after cycle 6 to assess response. Review in clinic in 3 weeks with blood tests.

cancer_timeline.value: Started capecitabine and temozolomide combination therapy
CT shows pancreatic primary 4.2cm with multiple liver metastases, largest 3.1cm in segment 7

patient_facts.value: Improved intermittent abdominal discomfort and early satiety
Abdomen soft and non-tender with no hepatomegaly
Stable liver function and adequate bone marrow reserve

status_updates.value: Metastatic pancreatic NET with stable disease on capecitabine/temozolomide after progression on lanreotide. Tolerating treatment well with clinical benefit.
Stable disease on CT with unchanged primary tumor and liver metastases
Grade 1 palmar-plantar syndrome and mild fatigue
Continuing with cycle 5 capecitabine/temozolomide at full dose
Review in clinic in 3 weeks with blood tests
